audio_caption: The audio clip begins with music, which sounds like light and easy listening. A male speaker then addresses someone, asking, “You okay?” and saying he's “gonna put a little blue sheet on you.” He then addresses a group, saying, "All right guys, we're getting ready to start an axillary abscess on a young patient. She's been having pain for several days. She came to the office today and we had an ultrasound done which showed a solid and cystic component in that area. So we're gonna just drain it today, put on some antibiotics to see how she does." He then turns to the patient saying, "All right dear, we're gonna start some numbing medicine, okay? It's gonna burn.” The audio clip concludes with the sound of his speech as he tells the patient, “Good job” and asks, “You doing okay?”

The audio clip begins with a male voice stating the burning sensation will go away in a couple of minutes. The voice continues to describe the draping process, mentioning two drapes on a person, including a sticky drape and a blue drape used to cover the body and maintain a sterile environment.

The audio clip features a conversation between two speakers, one male and one female. The male speaker suggests they might not need to go to the hospital for a small abscess, but then acknowledges it's causing the female severe pain and stiffness in her arm. He asks if she's doing okay and tells her he doesn't want it to hurt or bother her. There is the sound of liquid being squeezed out of a wound.

The clip starts with a male speaker saying, "We're going to culture this and send it to the lab for testing." He continues, saying someone will look a whole lot better after this tear. He then remarks, "Ooh, yes," followed by asking if someone is okay, noting that there is a lot of pus in there, speaking in a reassuring tone.

The audio clip begins with a squishing sound, suggestive of pressure being applied to something. A male speaker then comments, "I can squeeze the pus out of there," and notes, "There's so much pus." He asks, in a reassuring tone, "Feeling any better?" He follows up by saying something along the lines of, "All this pus and facial will be gone. You're gonna feel a whole lot better." The squishing sound returns, continuing the actions implied by the speaker.

The audio clip features a male speaker, sounding professional, explaining something, likely in a medical setting, mentioning "skin" and "tight compartments", and that "sudden increase in size of volume causes a lot of pressure". A female voice interjects with, "it hurts". The male speaker responds with sympathy and encouragement, saying, "yeah, I'm sorry honey, almost done, sweetie", suggesting a comforting tone. He repeats "almost done".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker, who sounds like a doctor, saying he believes the patient had an "infected sebaceous cyst." He further clarifies that there was a cyst that got infected and asks if the patient is in pain. The male speaker explains, presumably while performing a procedure, that he's dealing with an infected sebaceous cyst and its wall, trying to clean it further. He then asks the patient how she is doing. Sounds of light medical procedures are present. The male speaker continues to speak to the patient, reassuring her and trying to clean out "the wall of the cyst." The speaker then says, "You're doing great, you're a brave girl." The audio clip ends with the male speaker stating that it looks pretty clean inside.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a wound dressing process, mentioning the initial use of povidone-iodine-soaked gauze followed by a switch to regular saline-soaked or dry gauze depending on the wound's appearance. The tone is informative and practical.

The clip begins with a male speaker who explains that "the packing is really tight" and discusses the process and expected ease of the procedure. He then announces to his audience that "we're just about done with this case" after draining "the axillary abscess from infected sebaceous cyst" under local anesthesia. He notes that the patient has done well and can go home after eating, drinking, and taking antibiotics. The sound of a steady, high-pitched tone is present.
